text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: ETHEL ETTA JAMESON daughter

Present Address: 102-1st Ave., Melfort, Walter Eatonman

Pioneer Address: Melfort

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1901

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? about 10

How many of these were bachelor's homes? only 2 I can remember

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? not often

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? without an invitation

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? early afternoon usually

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Sometimes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Someone stayed home

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, some

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Dances in the school & in a few homes that were large enough but I was not allowed to dance, as my father was a local preacher for the Methodist Church & they did not believe in dancing nor card playing.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

Former Recreation and Social Life

1. In the first ten years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's houses only? How many of these were bachelor's houses only?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Rare you ever invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Without our invitation.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Early afternoon usually.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Sometimes.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (E.g., was the term to "make possible" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "meets" where groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, once.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "meets" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

The school was used for church services for Anglican, Presbyterian & Methodist congregations taking turns on different Sundays.

9. When was your first community hall built? Community Halls were not common until years later.

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

always a school barn for horses

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Whist

Was there card playing for a prize? Yes

What dances were popular? Square & round dances

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

It was frowned upon by those of the Methodist faith, the Presbyterians tolerated it & the Anglicans enjoyed their card games.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, book socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc.) If you have not described these on the School Questionnaire, give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? How large was it?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? How was it used?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? Did you obtain permission from local authorities to use the hall in town for other functions, etc., or make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? What dances were popular?

Was there card playing for a prize?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or in community gatherings? Explain.

The party theme tolerated by the youngsters enjoyed thus card games.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? In the new town, yes, we had our "stay at home" once a month when callers came with cards on the hall table.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? To some extent.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Only if one of the parties who married had been a widow or widower.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Methodist Church Ladies Aid Organized in March 1904

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

A church was being built but it was found necessary to get the help of the women. Of course it was customary.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

During post World War when sugar & flour prices were so high.

Was incorporated June 11th 1914

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Possibly 50%

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

mostly buying by carload lots & distributing to shareholders from the distillery's home before the store was built sometime later.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No, not in early days.

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What activities did you participate in during your time at the school? Do you remember any special events such as picnics, plays, or parties?

13. Was there a church in your community? If so, what was its name?

14. Describe any other details of your life at the school, such as the food served, the teachers, and any extracurricular activities.

15. What was the name of the first organization established in your community?

16. What was the date and reason for its establishment?

17. Was there a Homemakers Club in your district? How many women belonged to it?

18. Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes. Include clubs (for women or young people) which included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

The Agricultural Society was one of the early organizations for the promotion of better crops and cattle. It still functions now as one of the best clubs in the town.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

The fairs were always popular and continued to be one of the most highly making projects. The Agro Soc. sold life memberships, B.C.F.T., annual canvass, town grants.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? The Agro Society met at the Secretary's Office, B.C.F.T. in same office as the above mentioned. They also met at the Town Hall which was used for a hall.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Sometimes

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Chatanooga was a source of information and entertainment for some years. Wallace Reid and touring companies from Toronto and other distant points were invited to entertain the citizens.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Yes Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Ball, Steal the wedge, marbles were scarce unless they came from the clay which some did.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Ball, Steal the wedge, Skipping rope.
4. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1924, giving their name or names, date when it was first organized, its activities, purpose, who belonged (name, where, young people's), whether it still exists.

5. What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

6. Did you often have magic lantern shows? If so, give dates if possible.

7. Who provided the lantern and the slides?

8. What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

9. What games did boys play in summer (mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

10. What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

11. Ball. What was the word for which some said...
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *Playing on snowshoes, shinny, with a puck like hockey but generally homemade block/wood & homemade stick with a bulge.*  
   What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *Games were mostly played at school during recess. It was a long way home & chores to be done.*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   *Not that I ever heard of in this community.*

**PICNICS AND SPORTS.**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   *July 1st 1901*

26. Who organized it?  
   *Community*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *For the Community*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   *Yes*  
   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?  
   *No*

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *Ball games, football & baseball. Foot races. Do music. A kid would jump out of his pants & run in his shirt tail. Everyone ought to be made at all, just natural to be faster.*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *Families & friends formed smaller groups at this first one, soon after there were refreshments booths.*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *Ham sandwiches. Hard boiled eggs, tea & coffee*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *About 1 PM to dark.*
5. What winter games were played outside? Fox and hounds, skating, sledding, etc.

22. Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was work the chief activity?

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo horns, arrowheads, etc., or games in the open air?

PIONEER AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, game organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating—was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

It was something new for one to see Indians from Algoma with their papooses on their backs. Recently from Ontario we never had primitive Indians in Ottawa county.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Baseball was quite popular even since there was a community, young men, some organized, used to play on main street during most Thursdays evening, when the town was young & mostly.

For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Winter 1913-04. Skated on slough on the outskirts of the new town.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? Skating & Curling. Do not know the date but well before 1914. Young men & then women used the slough all one winter, no children. Presently when children came the rink was built about 1910 when my son William was 6 years old. Sister Edith & both could skate & won prizes at carnival.
Describe any features of this place which you remember or imagine.

31. Describe any different kinds of places which you knew of in the early days, such as the school, church, park, school, or Sunday School, parties, activities, games, etc., tell what they were like.

32. What changes have you noticed in Pinawa since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

33. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in them.

34. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1917, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against other teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

35. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

36. Tell about the making of the new barn.

37. Tell about the making of the new school.

38. Tell about the making of the new church.

39. Tell about the making of the new hall.

40. Tell about the making of the new post office.

41. Tell about the making of the new fire hall.

42. Tell about the making of the new library.

43. Tell about the making of the new hospital.

44. Tell about the making of the new police station.

45. Tell about the making of the new fire station.

46. Tell about the making of the new school.

47. Tell about the making of the new park.

48. Tell about the making of the new playground.

49. Tell about the making of the new cemetery.

50. Tell about the making of the new cemetery.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?

Not that I ever heard. Soon after the first school was built in 1904, a book store was established in the new town.
40. When did an annual sports day become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community games?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
   When was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st?)

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball, or other teams? Give names and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you bought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kinds of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. Was books sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?
   Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library?
   Then was it begun?
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for pupils to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?

Note that over twenty years after the first school was built in 1904, a book store was established in the town.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it
   contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian,
   and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to
    the west?
    Continued to have the Ottawa Journal & Montreal
    Family Herald for some years after coming west. A local
    newspaper was established then in 1916. Then soon we
    started reading the Saskatoon Star.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped cer-
    tain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading
    material? No
    Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your
    early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
    No. We could always send to Eaton's in Toronto
    for anything we particularly wanted.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   In what year?
   If so, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian.

Tell what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. That newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to this valley?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you changed our
    rate subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading
    material? Yes

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your
    early days in the west a handicap? Possibly.

We could always count on Eaton's in Toronto.

For anything we particularly wanted.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? An Organ

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violin

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

Piano for the family in 1910 or eleven

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started? 1906

Who started it? Young men 8

How long did it continue?

How many were in it? 15

Who was bandmaster? Mr. Walter Steigman

What instruments were included? With them, cornets, slide trombones, saxophones, drums, horns.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

No uniforms at first. Played for various events, made a trip to Prince Albert. It had the parade time on the occasion of Sir Robert Borden's first visit to western Can. in 1907. I think I have a picture which I will send you presently.
Musical Instrumentation

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Olive

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainments in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

In the community?

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? If so, who started it? How many were in it? What instruments were included? Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where? If members had uniforms, what were they and played for.

I have a picture which I will send you presently.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

General

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the media?

65. Is there an important event in your community now or recently ended with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests:

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you began collecting, and any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc., regularly?

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL:

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of former days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary.)
Oxford

No. 613 S

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1A8
